articles.headline: Economic Data Points to Upward Trajectory
articles.snippet: The Commerce Department said the economy grew at a 4.2 percent rate, but businesses still seem to be benefiting more than consumers.
articles.abstract: The Commerce Department said the economy grew at a 4.2 percent rate, but businesses still seem to be benefiting more than consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy grew faster than first thought last quarter, the Commerce Department said on Thursday, the latest in a series of signals that point to a period of sustainable growth ahead.

articles.headline: Shell Submits a Plan for New Exploration of Alaskan Arctic Oil
articles.snippet: The company, which had experienced setbacks in its efforts in recent years, said it had not yet made a final decision on whether to drill next summer.
articles.abstract: The company, which had experienced setbacks in its efforts in recent years, said it had not yet made a final decision on whether to drill next summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Royal Dutch Shell submitted a plan to the federal government on Thursday to try once again to explore for oil in the Alaskan Arctic, following years of legal and logistical setbacks as well as dogged opposition from environmentalists.

articles.headline: As Ebola Grips Liberia’s Capital, a Quarantine Sows Social Chaos
articles.snippet: Monrovia has become, in a few short weeks, a major focal point of the epidemic, with the outbreak overwhelming the government of President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf.
articles.abstract: Monrovia has become, in a few short weeks, a major focal point of the epidemic, with the outbreak overwhelming the government of President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Some people are swimming in and out of the Ebola quarantine zone in this seaside capital. One man slips out every day to reach his job at a Western embassy. Another has turned his living room into a tollbooth, charging others to escape through his apartment at the edge of the cordoned area. Countless others have used a different method: bribing their way out with fees that soldiers determine according to a person’s appearance, circumstances and even gender.

articles.headline: A New American Oil Bonanza
articles.snippet: United States refinery production in recent weeks reached record highs and left supply depots flush, cushioning the impact of all the instability surrounding traditional global oil fields.
articles.abstract: United States refinery production in recent weeks reached record highs and left supply depots flush, cushioning the impact of all the instability surrounding traditional global oil fields.
articles.lead_paragraph: THREE RIVERS, Tex. — Whenever overseas turmoil has pushed energy prices higher in the past, John and Beth Hughes have curbed their driving by eating at home more and shopping locally. But the current crises in Ukraine and Iraq did not stop them from making the two-hour drive to San Antonio to visit the Alamo, have a chicken fried steak lunch, and buy fish for their tank before driving home to Corpus Christi.

articles.headline: Obama Urges Calm in Face of Crises in Ukraine and Syria
articles.snippet: President Obama confronted two volatile crises with restraint Thursday, saying he was not close to authorizing airstrikes in Syria and playing down an escalation of Russia’s intervention in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: President Obama confronted two volatile crises with restraint Thursday, saying he was not close to authorizing airstrikes in Syria and playing down an escalation of Russia’s intervention in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama confronted a pair of volatile international crises with restraint on Thursday as he said he was not close to authorizing airstrikes against Islamic extremists in Syria and played down the latest escalation of Russia’s military intervention in Ukraine.

articles.headline: Businesses Are Winning Cat-and-Mouse Tax Game
articles.snippet: Corporations are finding ways to legally avoid paying federal taxes, causing business income tax revenue to be stagnant.
articles.abstract: Corporations are finding ways to legally avoid paying federal taxes, causing business income tax revenue to be stagnant.
articles.lead_paragraph: A pharmaceutical company moved its headquarters to Ireland, sharply reducing its tax rate. A billboard company reclassified itself as a real estate concern, meaning it will no longer pay corporate taxes. And a big oil producer split itself in two, cleaving off a multibillion-dollar division that now operates tax-free.

articles.headline: In China, Detecting Fraud Riskier Than Doing It
articles.snippet: Researching a Canadian company that mines in China resulted in a Chinese-born Canadian citizen being arrested, terrorized and prohibited from leaving China.
articles.abstract: Researching a Canadian company that mines in China resulted in a Chinese-born Canadian citizen being arrested, terrorized and prohibited from leaving China.
articles.lead_paragraph: It can be very risky to do things in China that are taken for granted in other countries.

articles.headline: Evictions Soar in Hot Market; Renters Suffer
articles.snippet: Fueled by a growing interest in urban living and a shortage of rental housing, rents have risen sharply in cities like Milwaukee and San Francisco and in states like Maine, Georgia and Kentucky.
articles.abstract: Fueled by a growing interest in urban living and a shortage of rental housing, rents have risen sharply in cities like Milwaukee and San Francisco and in states like Maine, Georgia and Kentucky.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Just after 7 a.m., sheriff’s deputies knocked on the door of the duplex apartment, holding a fluorescent orange eviction notice. The process was quick and efficient. A moving crew began to carry out the family’s possessions and stack them neatly at the curb. Celeste Wilson, the tenant, appeared on the front step in pajama pants.

articles.headline: U.S. Identifies Citizens Joining Rebels in Syria, Including ISIS
articles.snippet: Nearly a dozen Americans are known to have traveled to Syria to fight for the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the militant group that the Obama administration says poses the greatest threat to the United States since Al Qaeda before the Sept. 11,...
articles.abstract: Nearly a dozen Americans are known to have traveled to Syria to fight for the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the militant group that the Obama administration says poses the greatest threat to the United States since Al Qaeda before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence and law enforcement agencies have identified nearly a dozen Americans who have traveled to Syria to fight for the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the militant group that the Obama administration says poses the greatest threat to the United States since Al Qaeda before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Sam Kass, the Obamas’ Foodmaster General
articles.snippet: Mr. Kass, the first family’s personal chef, has one of the highest public profiles of anyone in the East Wing and a window into the zealously guarded space and tastes of the Obama White House.
articles.abstract: Mr. Kass, the first family’s personal chef, has one of the highest public profiles of anyone in the East Wing and a window into the zealously guarded space and tastes of the Obama White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Back in 2005, when President Obama was a mere freshman senator, his wife, Michelle, found herself overwhelmed with the stress of being a full-time working mother, largely alone in her Chicago home, with two daughters who got sick a little too often. Sluggish and above her fighting weight, she wondered if her family’s diet — lots of prepared food and a few too many Cheetos — might need an adjustment.

articles.headline: Praising Rebels, Putin Toughens Tone on Ukraine
articles.snippet: As separatists seized a strategically located town in southeast Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin issued a congratulatory message to the insurgents.
articles.abstract: As separatists seized a strategically located town in southeast Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin issued a congratulatory message to the insurgents.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As Russian-backed rebels entrenched themselves in a newly captured, strategically located town in southeast Ukraine on Friday, President Vladimir V. Putin bluntly strengthened Moscow’s hard-line position that the government in Kiev must be compelled to negotiate regional autonomy.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Chief Executive of Rovio, Maker of Angry Birds Game, to Step Down
articles.snippet: The move by Mikael Hed comes as the Finnish company struggles to respond to an increasing trend toward so-called freemium games.
articles.abstract: The move by Mikael Hed comes as the Finnish company struggles to respond to an increasing trend toward so-called freemium games.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The chief Angry Bird is leaving the nest.
